answers.title: No provider for ManagedZone
answers.body:
adding providers: [materialProviders] to the component where I used the <material-button> fixed the issue.

This provider seems to be required for the ripple effect.

Thanks for the hint to BrownRiceRice https://github.com/dart-lang/angular2_components/issues/14#issuecomment-257914810

comments.body: See the link on the answer ;) TL;DR it's like annotation in other langages.

answers.title: What does const mean?
answers.body:
const means a compile-time constant. Been constant it can be optimized and instantiated only once.

const [HeroDetailComponent] means that the list is a compile time constant. Compile-time constants are mandatory when used as metadata (in your case directives is a named parameter of @Component() that is a metadata of your class).

title: What does const mean?
body:
I am using angular2dart and want to know, why do I have to pass keyword const on:

directives: const [HeroDetailComponent]

component properties.

comments.body: It seems they are waiting for DDC to become available to target Polymer 2.0. Polymer Dart 1.0 is rather stale.

I interpret the brief statement in youtube.com/watch?v=JXcNqXbCa0E as the Dart Polymer wrapper is abandoned. The inactivity on the github repo backs this. As Günter mentions above the DDC dev environment and js Polymer 2.0 with ES6, seems as a good match, but nothing stated.

polymerize is an individual's attempt to continue the work.  I was looking at this earlier.  I am not unopposed to others picking up the mantel and continuing but in the eyes of Google, it looks abandoned.  The issue is that this build is very volatile and experimental it seems, so it isnt something i would want in production code.

answers.title: Is PolymerDart dead? An architecture issue
answers.body:
After watching the talks it seems to me that the focus is more on making angular2 dart, the angular 2 dart components and the dev compiler more stable and robust.

It's eventually not dead at the moment, but priorities might have shifted.

Thus, you might want to give https://pub.dartlang.org/packages/polymerize a try.

title: Is PolymerDart dead? An architecture issue
body:
Given the information at both the Polymer and Dart conferences in the last week, there is no information mentioned about the intersection of polymer and dart called PolymerDart at neither of them (except a passing wave, 2 word statement in 1 slide at the dart conference after watching the conference a second time). Given the last commit for it has been in July, only adding some tests for PolymerDart I am leaning towards yes.

I have been looking into a variety of other sources and it seems that while Polymer and Dart are separately going to continue on their own things respectively, there is no support any longer for the union. Polymer is focused entirely on PolymerJs and web component standards, where as Dart is pushing deep into AngularDart and its associated architecture. It seems that after looking deeper into it, the Googlers who were managing this union was in fact a side project, which does not actually have set resources, so there isnt a defined team in place for PolymerDart compatibility.

Given this information and the fact that Google regularly releases a lot of things, some thrive and some die all the time. They let the community determine it, and is shown over and over again throughout their many projects.

Has anyone else obtained any information related deeper into this? All my signs are pointing to it being dead. That said, maybe i should be looking to migrate my team from this and more towards angulardart.

I did as best as I could to only make note of facts and not opinions of any sort, as my opinions are not on trial, the continued development in a fast paced technology where stagnant codebases imply a dead-in-the-water technology.

comments.body: Thanks.  I wish Dart symbol literals are more powerful that they can be code completed, analyzer checked and also refactored.

Symbols are just dumb data, so completing them isn't really viable, not more than completing string content is. Most people shouldn't use them for anything (based on the assumption that most people shouldn't use reflection, and if you don't use reflection, you shouldn't need symbols). The Function.apply function and the noSuchMethod Invocation argument are reflective functions that are outside the mirrors library, and where you are most likely to encounter symbols as a normal user.

I dont like to use mirrors when it is not necessary. But i think Symbols have a very good use case in annotations.   1. In source generation to refer to members, etc.  2. In angular to bind, etc  Generally Strings are used in these cases. If Symbol literals support presence detection by analyzer, code completion by IDEs/analyzer and refractoring by IDEs/dart tools, it would be a big plus.  For example:      class User {       String name;     }      @EncodeField(#User.name, as: 'Name')     class Serializer implements MapSerializer<User> {       ...     }

answers.title: What are the use cases of multilevel Symbols?
answers.body:
There are different use-cases. Primarily, it represents a library name (library foo.bar.baz;). The mirror system uses it for that (see, e.g., https://api.dartlang.org/stable/1.20.1/dart-mirrors/MirrorSystem/findLibrary.html).

Secondarily, the mirror system is sometimes using it as a "qualified name" like library.name.ClassName.memberName to represent an exact class or library member (https://api.dartlang.org/stable/1.20.1/dart-mirrors/DeclarationMirror/qualifiedName.html).

It's not that useful outside of the mirror system.

title: What are the use cases of multilevel Symbols?
body:
Glossary: What I mean by multilevel Symbol is something that is like #Dummy.bar instead of single level like #bar. Dont know what is better name for it, sorry.

Symbols are very nifty. I can do:

class Foo {
 static String hello() => "Said hello!";
}

ClassMirror clMir = reflectType(Foo) as ClassMirror();
print(clMir.invoke(#hello, []));

It prints Said hello!. Great!

But one cant do:

class Bar{
 static final Bar bar = new Bar();
}

ClassMirror clMir = reflectType(Bar) as ClassMirror();
print(clMir.invoke(#bar.hello, []));

This would fail.

Also, I haven't found a place where you can get reflection for multilevel Symbol, like reflectSymbol(#Dummy.bar) and get InstanceMirror for bar or something similar.

So are there use cases for multilevel Symbols?

comments.body: pub.dartlang.org/packages/source_gen, pub.dartlang.org/packages/reflectable or dart:mirrors if it's not for the browser (dart2js with mirrors can cause code bloat for the resulting JS output file).
Thanks.  What is the syntax for converting a constructor to a function.  I would much rather do Foo(x, y) than new Foo(x, y).

answers.title: How can I create a dispatch table that creates different types of objects
answers.body:
Not really, no.

There is a syntax for converting a constructor to a function, but it isn't implemented everywhere yet, and it's likely to change in the future, so I don't recommend using it.

The alternative to having a make or create function is to write that function inline in the map: dart Map<int, Function> funcMap = {0: (v) => new A(v), 25: (v) => new Z(v)}; Whether that's more or less readable is a matter of taste.

title: How can I create a dispatch table that creates different types of objects
body:
If I define a bunch of classes:

class A  {
  final List<int> value;
  A(this.value);
  static make(List<int> value) => new A(value);
}
// more class defs here
class Z  {
  final List<String> value;
  Z(this.value);
  static make(List<String> value) => new A(value);
}

Then the following doesn't work, because Type has no methods

Map<int, Type> typeMap = {0: A, 25: Z};
new typeMap[0]([1, 2, 3])

But the following does work. Although, it takes lots of extra work to create the static make methods.

Map<int, Function> funcMap = {0: A.make, 25: Z.make};
funcMap[0]([1, 2, 3])

Is there a better way to do this?

title: How to get url path in angular2 dart
body:
I'm calling an URL like "123.123.123.123/client/12345" and would like to use a client-component to show the client with the id 12345 in my root component.

At the moment i'm using the Route class as follows:

@RouteConfig(const [
    const Route(path: '/:link/:id', name: 'start', component:RootComponent)])

and in RootComponent implements OnInit I have

final _routeParams;

RootComponent(this._routeParams);
Client client;

ngOnInit() async {
    var link = _routeParams.get('link');
    if (link=="client") {
          client = GetClientById(_routeParams.get("id"));
    }
 }

This isn't working. It's failing with the message "No provider for RouteParams!"

Does anybody know how to get the components of the URL in angular2, or should I just use standard dart url parsing?

<form>
    <input *ngFor="let val of vals; let idx = index" [ngModel]="val" ngControl="input-{{idx}}">
</form>

but in 2.0.0 updating vals with this approach causes EXCEPTION: The null object does not have a method 'updateValue'.

comments.body: in TypeScript, there is a "module.ts" where you should add import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms'; there must be something similar in Dart. Otherwise, if you add it on top of your component, it will work.

answers.title: Can't bind to 'ngModel' since it isn't a known native property or known directive
answers.body:
It seems you are missing transformers for common directives in your pubspec.yaml file.

Check https://github.com/angular-examples/toh-1/blob/master/pubspec.yaml it contains following transformers angular section:

transformers:
- angular2:
    platform_directives:
    - 'package:angular2/common.dart#COMMON_DIRECTIVES'
    platform_pipes:
    - 'package:angular2/common.dart#COMMON_PIPES'
    entry_points: web/main.dart

answers.title: Can't bind to 'ngModel' since it isn't a known native property or known directive
answers.body:
As of Angular 4, platform_directives is gone.

NgModel is a form directive now. You can include form directives as follows:

import 'package:angular_forms/angular_forms.dart' as forms;

@Component(
    selector: 'my-app',
    directives: const[forms.formDirectives],
)
class AppComponent {
}

comments.body: It took me way too long to find this answer.

answers.title: Can't bind to 'ngModel' since it isn't a known native property or known directive
answers.body:
Using dart 2.3.0 And following the tutorials. It's necessary to add directives: [formDirectives], as part of your component. And import import 'package:angular_forms/angular_forms.dart';

import 'package:angular/angular.dart';
import 'package:angular_forms/angular_forms.dart';

import 'hero.dart';

@Component(
  selector: 'my-app',
  template: '''
    <h1>{{title}}</h1>
    <h2>{{hero.name}}</h2>
    <div><label>id: </label>{{hero.id}}</div>
    <div>
      <label>name: </label>
      <input [(ngModel)]="hero.name" placeholder="name">
    </div>
  ''',
  directives: [formDirectives],
)
class AppComponent {
  final title = 'Tour of Heroes';
  Hero hero = Hero(1, 'Windstorm');
}

Check the repo with the tutorial example, fortunately, has been updated as long as Dart releases updates: https://github.com/angular-examples/toh-1/blob/master/lib/app_component.dart

title: Can't bind to 'ngModel' since it isn't a known native property or known directive
body:
I am trying to learn angular2dart and follow the tutorial from anguar2dart site.

Consider following code: 

import 'package:angular2/core.dart';

class Hero {
  final int id;
  String name;
  Hero(this.id, this.name);
}

@Component(
    selector: 'my-app',
    template: '''
      <h1>{{title}}</h1>
      <h2>{{hero.name}} details!</h2>
      <div><label>id: </label>{{hero.id}}</div>
      <div>
        <label>name: </label>
        <input [(ngModel)]="hero.name" placeholder="name">
      </div>'''
)
class AppComponent {
  String title = 'Tour of Heroes';
  Hero hero = new Hero(1, 'Windstorm');
}

When I compiled this, it shows me the error message:

Build error:
Transform TemplateCompiler on Sample|lib/app_component.ng_meta.json threw error: Template parse errors:
Can't bind to 'ngModel' since it isn't a known native property or known directive. Please fix typo or add to directives list. ("
      <div>
        <label>name: </label>
        <input [ERROR ->][(ngModel)]="hero.name" placeholder="name">
      </div>"): AppComponent@5:15

What am I doing wrong?

answers.title: Aqueduct/Dart new project command fails on Windows 7
answers.body:
Basically it seems that the command fails to switch directory before executing "pub get --no-packages-dir".

So when I replay "pub get" in the right directory, it seems to work.

EDIT : It's a problem with dart "Process.runSync()" method on windows which doesn't use the "PATH" env. When adding the "runInShell: true" parameters it seems to work. More details here : github

The question now is : Is it working as intended ?

answers.title: Dart protobuf: what version of protoc should I download?
answers.body:
You don't need anything special for JS. The compiler generates Dart code that gets compiled to JS

Install one of:

  • protoc-3.0.0-linux-x86_32.zip
  • protoc-3.0.0-linux-x86_64.zip
  • protoc-3.0.0-osx-x86_32.zip
  • protoc-3.0.0-osx-x86_64.zip
  • protoc-3.0.0-win32.zip

answers.title: Why does dart's listSync() behave differently on Windows and Ubuntu?
answers.body:
This (likely) is due to the (non)-Guarantee of the Windows FS.

From another post:

On a FAT filesystem, the entries in any given directory are unsorted, causing the tree-walk to be unsorted. NTFS directories, by contrast, are always sorted

You could always sort your output though:

var files = directory.listSync()..sort((a, b) => a.path.compareTo(b.path));

title: Why does dart's listSync() behave differently on Windows and Ubuntu?
body:
When I walk a directory using the listSync function in Windows the entries are sorted but when I run the same code in Ubuntu they are not:

Why is that?
